conclusion: Analyzing the motion of charged particles in a magnetic field.
Description of the magnetic field and particle source setup.
Particles have a charge-to-mass ratio of 2×10⁶ C/kg and are emitted in the first quadrant.
Collection device is placed along the positive x-axis.
Objective is to find the velocity v₁ when particles reach the collection device.
Charged particles in a magnetic field experience a force resulting in circular motion.
Radius of circular motion is r = v/(|q/m|·B).
For negatively charged particles, the path is clockwise.
Calculate radius: r = v/(2×10⁶ × 5×10⁻³) = v/10⁴ meters.
Particle's trajectory is a portion of a circle from S to the x-axis.
Image shows r₁ as the radius and v₁ as the final velocity.
For particle to reach x-axis, r ≥ 1.2m, so v ≥ 1.2×10⁴ m/s.
Since speed remains constant, v₁ = v.
Image suggests a right triangle with height 1.2m and radius r.
Final velocity v₁ when reaching the collection device is 16,000 m/s.
